properties.Name: Chromosome
properties.Description:
A chromosome is simply a very long piece of DNA that cells can easily copy. 
Chromosomes are made of DNA and protein.
It helps keep DNA organized and compact. 

Every chromosome contains a single molecule of DNA.

Proteins keep the DNA folded into an orderly, compact shape.
The largest chromosome of an organism is generally referred to as chromosome 1, the next largest as chromosome 2, and so on. 
Different chromosomes contain different genes. That is, each chromosome contains a specific chunk of the genome.
Each chromosome has a constriction point called the centromere, which divides the chromosome into two sections, or "arms." The short arm of the chromosome is labeled the "p arm." The long arm of the chromosome is labeled the "q arm."     The location of the centromere on each chromosome gives the chromosome its characteristic shape, and can be used to help describe the location of specific genes.

 
New cells get their chromosomes from old cells through cell division, or mitosis.     In preparation for mitosis, a cell makes a copy of each of its chromosomes, building replicas of each DNA molecule and the packaging proteins.    If all goes according to plan each new cell ends up with a full set of chromosomes.
Though similar in basic appearance, different chromosomes vary slightly in size and shape. In addition, when chromosomes are stained with fluorescent dyes they develop distinctive patterns of bright and dark bands. These subtle differences enable cell biologists to distinguish different chromosomes from one another.
Human Chromosomes
The entire DNA in a human body is packaged in  23 pairs of chromosomes = 46 total.
Twenty-two of these pairs, called autosomes, look the same in both males and females. The 23rd pair, the sex chromosomes, differ between males and females.

Chromosomes (and genes) are made up of the 4 letters of DNA. And cells read the letters found in stretches of DNA called genes to make proteins that help our bodies and minds run properly.

There is also DNA on the chromosome string between the genes. This DNA is called "non-coding DNA."  The non-coding DNA has become useful in defining biological relationships and obtaining solid evidence in forensic laboratory evaluations.

Columns.Name: ChromosomeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a chromosome.

Columns.Name: ChromosomeNumber
Columns.Description: The number assigned to the Chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfGenes
Columns.Description: The number of genes contained in the chromosome.

Columns.Name: TotalNumberOfBasePairs
Columns.Description: The total number of base pairs contained in the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfSequencedBasedPairs
Columns.Description: The number of sequenced based pairs contained in the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfShortArmBasepairs
Columns.Description: The number of chromosome short arm 7p basepairs.

Columns.Name: NumberOfLongArmBasepairs
Columns.Description: The number of chromosome long arm 7q basepairs.

Columns.Name: OverallMaleAverageGeneticSize
Columns.Description: The overall male average genetic size.

Columns.Name: OverallFemaleAverageGeneticSize
Columns.Description: The overall female average genetic size.

Columns.Name: AverageRecombinationLengthCmMb
Columns.Description: The average recombination length of the chromosome in cM/MB.

Columns.Name: IscnTranslocationNomenclature
Columns.Description:
The designation t(A;B)(p1;q2) is used to denote a translocation between chromosome A and chromosome B. 

The information in the second set of parentheses, when given, gives the precise location within the chromosome for chromosomes A and B respectively-with p indicating the short arm of the chromosome, q indicating the long arm, and the numbers after p or q refers to regions, bands and sub-bands.

Columns.Name: FusedGeneNomenclature
Columns.Description: The nomenclature of the fused gene.

Columns.Name: NumberOfNovelGenes
Columns.Description: The number of Novel genes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfPartialGenes
Columns.Description: The number of partial genes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfPredictedGenes
Columns.Description: The number of predicted genes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfPutativeNonCodingGenes
Columns.Description: The number of putative non-coding genes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfTcrGeneSegments
Columns.Description: The number of TCR gene segments of the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfTcrPseudogenes
Columns.Description: The number of TCR pseudogenes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfPseudogenes
Columns.Description: The number of pseudogenes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: NumberOfOverlappingGenes
Columns.Description: The number of overlapping genes associated with the chromosome.

Columns.Name: PercentageOfChromosomeTranscribed
Columns.Description: The percentage of the chromosome that has been transcribed.

Columns.Name: ChromosomeTelomere
Columns.Description:
Telomeres are distinctive structures found at the ends of our chromosomes. They consist of the same short DNA sequence repeated over and over again.

In humans, as well as all other vertebrates, the telomere sequence is TTAGGG.

Telomeres serve three major purposes:

-  They help to organize each of our 46 chromosomes in the nucleus 

-  They protect the ends of our chromosomes by forming a cap without which our chromosomes may end up sticking to other chromosomes.

-  They allow the chromosome to be replicated properly during cell division.

Every time a cell carries out DNA replication the chromosomes are shortened by about 25-200 bases (A, C, G, or T) per replication.  However, because the ends are protected by telomeres, the only part of the chromosome that is lost, is the telomere, and the DNA is left undamaged.   Without telomeres, important DNA would be lost every time a cell divides.

Columns.Name: BalancedChromosomeTranslocationIndicator
Columns.Description: Translocations can be balanced (in an even exchange of material with no genetic information extra or missing.

Columns.Name: UnbalancedChromosomeTranslocationIndicator
Columns.Description: Where the exchange of chromosome material is unequal resulting in extra or missing genes).

Columns.Name: DuplicatedChromosomeIndicator
Columns.Description: Chromosomes are single linear strands, whereas duplicated chromosomes contain two identical copies joined by a centromere.

Columns.Name: ProkaryoticChromosomeIndicator
Columns.Description: Prokaryotic chromosomes are single, circular, and do not contain a histone scaffold which means they are not composed of chromatin.

Columns.Name: EukaryoticChromosomeIndicator
Columns.Description: Eukaryotic chromosomes are composed of chromatin and are multiple and linear.

Columns.Name: UnduplicatedChromosomeIndicator
Columns.Description: Chromosomes are single linear strands, whereas duplicated chromosomes contain two identical copies joined by a centromere.

Columns.Name: AcrocentricChromosomeIndicator
Columns.Description:
Acrocentric chromosomes are those with the
centromere very close to the outer tip, giving the chromosome a 'V' shaped appearance. 
The acrocentric chromosomes are numbers 13, 14, 15, 21 and 22.

Columns.Name: ChromosomeClassificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a chromosome classification.

Columns.Name: ChromosomeTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a chromosome type.

Properties.Description:
A chromosome is simply a very long piece of DNA that cells can easily copy. 
Chromosomes are made of DNA and protein.
It helps keep DNA organized and compact. 

Every chromosome contains a single molecule of DNA.

Proteins keep the DNA folded into an orderly, compact shape.
The largest chromosome of an organism is generally referred to as chromosome 1, the next largest as chromosome 2, and so on. 
Different chromosomes contain different genes. That is, each chromosome contains a specific chunk of the genome.
Each chromosome has a constriction point called the centromere, which divides the chromosome into two sections, or "arms." The short arm of the chromosome is labeled the "p arm." The long arm of the chromosome is labeled the "q arm."     The location of the centromere on each chromosome gives the chromosome its characteristic shape, and can be used to help describe the location of specific genes.

 
New cells get their chromosomes from old cells through cell division, or mitosis.     In preparation for mitosis, a cell makes a copy of each of its chromosomes, building replicas of each DNA molecule and the packaging proteins.    If all goes according to plan each new cell ends up with a full set of chromosomes.
Though similar in basic appearance, different chromosomes vary slightly in size and shape. In addition, when chromosomes are stained with fluorescent dyes they develop distinctive patterns of bright and dark bands. These subtle differences enable cell biologists to distinguish different chromosomes from one another.
Human Chromosomes
The entire DNA in a human body is packaged in  23 pairs of chromosomes = 46 total.
Twenty-two of these pairs, called autosomes, look the same in both males and females. The 23rd pair, the sex chromosomes, differ between males and females.

Chromosomes (and genes) are made up of the 4 letters of DNA. And cells read the letters found in stretches of DNA called genes to make proteins that help our bodies and minds run properly.

There is also DNA on the chromosome string between the genes. This DNA is called "non-coding DNA."  The non-coding DNA has become useful in defining biological relationships and obtaining solid evidence in forensic laboratory evaluations.
